Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, Slack notifications pinging like insistent birds. My grandson, Ethan, wandered in, his face a mix of excitement and uncertainty. “Grandpa, how did you know what you wanted to do with your life?” he asked, eyes searching mine for some kind of anchor. I felt the weight of his question—he was on the cusp of high school, anxious about choices and futures. I wanted to give him the kind of thoughtful, patient guidance my own grandfather once gave me.

But my phone buzzed again. The product manager’s message flashed: “Need your input on the API structure ASAP. Teams are waiting.” The launch date had been moved up, and every minute I delayed meant architects from three teams sat idle, their work at a standstill. My mind raced, torn between the urgency of my job and the quiet, pressing need of the boy in front of me. I could see Ethan’s hopefulness, and I could feel the pressure from my team. My heart ached as I wrestled with which role needed me more in this moment.
